description: Principles of clinical pharmacology are applied to the nursing care of family members. Proper prescribing and monitoring procedures for the various drug regimens used to treat various disease states are reviewed. Problems inherent in self-medication, overuse and abuse of drugs are also considered.
name: APPLIED PHARMACOLOGY IN NURSING PRACTICE

values.comments:
The course applies principles of clinical pharmacology to the nursing care of family members. Proper prescribing and monitoring procedures for the various drug regimens used to treat various disease states are reviewed. The class also considers problems inherent in self-medication and the overuse and abuse of drugs.

Students generally found the course to be "informative" and thought that it provided ample preparation in nursing practice. Many said that the class covered a lot of material, but that it was "broken down into manageable parts." Some students felt that the material was "too specific."

The class was taught by Professor Boullata and Professor Carey. Many students felt that the professors were "awesome" and enjoyed their lectures. One student remarked, "Carey's lectures, knowledge, and questions were excellent." However, some students reported that teaching methods varied between the two instructors, causing inconsistencies on exams. Some students also remarked that there were too many guest lecturers.

Many students felt that the workload was heavy and that the exams were "overwhelming" and "ridiculous." Several students expressed displeasure with having only two heavily-weighted exams, but found the quizzes to be "fair." The pre-requisite for the course is NURS 607.
